Package com.fasterxml.util.membuf

Package that contains public API of the the library.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ChunkyMemBuffer Generic type for MemBuffers that store data as chunks: sequences of primitive types with length, so that each read will read exact sequence of values that was appended.
MemBuffer Class that defines generic memory buffer interface.
StreamyMemBuffer Generic type for MemBuffers that store data as contiguous sequence of primitive values, so units of appending and reading do not necessarily match.
 

Class Summary
ChunkyBytesMemBuffer ChunkyMemBuffer for buffering byte sequences.
ChunkyLongsMemBuffer  
MemBuffersForBytes Factory for creating ChunkyBytesMemBuffers, memory buffers that contain byte sequences.
MemBuffersForLongs Factory for creating ChunkyBytesMemBuffers, memory buffers that contain byte sequences.
Segment<S extends Segment<S>> Core definition of containers for individual segments that form physical storage level of the logical queue.
SegmentAllocator<T extends Segment<T>> Shared allocator object, used by standardl MemBuffer implementations.
StreamyBytesMemBuffer Byte-valued StreamyMemBuffer: memory buffer that stores sequence of bytes without preserving boundaries between different appends (that is, contents of a single append can be retrieved using multiple reads, as well as contents of multiple appends can be retrieved with a single read)
StreamyLongsMemBuffer Long-valued StreamyMemBuffer: memory buffer that stores sequence of longs without preserving boundaries between different appends (that is, contents of a single append can be retrieved using multiple reads, as well as contents of multiple appends can be retrieved with a single read)
 

Enum Summary
Segment.State Enumeration listing usual states a segment can be in.
 

Package com.fasterxml.util.membuf Description

Package that contains public API of the the library.

For full usage, check out project home, but here is an example of simple usage:

First thing you need is a factory to create MemBuffer instance you want. Buffers come in multiple flavors, divided by two main criteria:

  • Type of values buffered: one of primitive types like "byte" or "long"
  • Bundling of values: either "chunky" (value sequence boundaries are preserved so that each read matches append that added value sequence) and "streamy" (boundaries NOT preserved: stream-style)
There is one factory for each value type, so we have:
  • MemBuffersForBytes for byte sequence buffering
  • MemBuffersForLong for long sequence buffering
To create byte-based buffer, you will thus do: 
  // use segments of 64kB; allocate 2 first, allocate at most 16
  // (i.e. max memory usage ~1MB)
  MemBuffersForBytes bufs = new MemBuffersForBytes(64 * 1024, 2, 16);
this factory object can create both "chunky" and "streamy" buffers: assuming you want to preserve byte boundaries you would use: 
  // create buffer that starts with a single 64kB segment;
  // and can expand to up to 192kB
  ChunkyBytesMemBuffer items = bufs.createChunkyBuffer(1, 4);
Buffer instances are then used to append entries, and read them in FIFO order: 
byte[] dataEntry = ...; // serialize from, say, JSON
items.appendEntry(dataEntry);
Or if you don't want an exception if there is no more room: 
if (!items.tryAppendEntry(dataEntry)) {
   // recover? Drop entry? Log?
}
and you can read appended entries in FIFO order: 
byte[] next = items.getNextEntry(); // blocks if nothing available
// or:
next = items.getNextEntryIfAvailable();
if (next == null) { // nothing yet available
    //...
}
// or:
next = items.getNextEntry(1000L); // block for at most 1 second before giving up
And that's it for basics -- head to the project home, for more info!
